repnme.cdata!: A better managed education system on Uganda

abstracts.cdata!:
As part of a policy aimed at providing
            universal access to primary education, the government of
            Uganda in 1997 eliminated primary school fees. The result
            was almost doubling of enrollments which schools were
            unprepared to accommodate and that put the school system on
            the verge of collapse under tremendous pressure.
            International Development Association (IDA) provided
            emergency funds to finance the education sector budget and
            to respond to the surge of enrollments. Education sector
            adjustment credit (ESAC) provided the framework for a
            harmonized and coordinated donor support to the sector.
            Uganda's own universal primary education policy
            resulted in an increase in primary school enrolment from 3.1
            million in 1996 to 7.3 million in 2006 and removed wealth
            and gender gaps among primary pupils. The institutional
            structure also provided a platform that includes civil
            society for continuous policy dialogue - particularly to
            improve learning quality and retention.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Primary Education and Teacher
            Decelopment and Education Sector Adjustment Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the projects are as
            follows: The outcome of the Primary Education and Teacher
            Development Project is moderately satisfactory, while the
            outcome for the Education Sector Adjustment Credit Project
            is satisfactory; for both, project sustainability is likely,
            institutional development impact is substantial, and Bank
            and Borrower performances are satisfactory overall.  Theses
            were the lessons learned concerning Bank support to
            expansion of primary education: 1) Very rapid expansion of
            enrollments, even with appropriate increase in funding, is
            liable to disrupt efforts to improve the efficiency and
            effectiveness of systems for delivering inputs to schools
            and for monitoring the quality of learning processes and
            outputs. Thorough diagnosis is needed of the weaknesses in
            these systems and of the time. needed to rectify them, to
            determine absorptive capacity. Attention should be given to
            prioritization and sequencing, to avoid overloading the
            reform agenda.  2) To protect the quality of education while
            expanding the capacity of the system, project design should
            be based on analysis of existing strengths and weaknesses at
            the school and classroom levels, providing a baseline for
            monitoring relevant indicators.  3) "Big bang"
            expansion of primary enrollments has long-term downstream
            fiscal implications beyond just the primary sub-sector.
            Uganda is confronting the need to increase capital and
            recurrent funding to post-primary education, now that pupils
            in the universal primary education (UPE) bulge are
            completing the primary cycle. Growth in the number of
            teachers has become a major issue for the public service
            payroll as a whole and is inhibiting pay reform. Lessons
            concerning use of adjustment lending through a sector-wide
            approach (SWAP) for education include the following: 1) The
            combination of budget support and investment lending can be
            an effective form of Bank support to expand primary
            education in countries with commitment to good policies but
            weak capacity to implement them. The two projects were
            mutually supportive. 2) Given strong ministry leadership, a
            SWAP can be quickly established, with benefits for the
            coherence of sector strategy, the quality and national
            ownership of sector policies, and transparency of sector
            planning and budget processes, but it presents new issues
            for aid management.  3) Maintaining donor and public
            confidence depends on special measures for fiduciary
            assurance which can be difficult to sustain.

            jumped by 70 percent in one year - from 3.1 million in 1996
            to 5.1 million in 1997. With the education sector adjustment
            credit, the World Bank and the Ugandan government have
            successfully tackled this challenge, and in less than three
            years, the has project helped increase access to basic
            education and substantially reduce the wealth and gender
            inequity in primary schools.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Education Sector Adjustment
            Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education Sector Adjustment
            Operation Project's outcome is rated as highly
            satisfactory. Continued good macroeconomic performance in
            the second half of the 1990s and increased international
            support for debt relief program created the financial space
            that allowed Uganda to allocate significant additional
            resources to primary education. The lessons learned from the
            implementation of the project include: 1) Budget support can
            be an effective instrument to support accelerated education
            development. It helps overcome the recurrent costs -
            especially teacher's salary - constraints that can
            undermine the quality of instruction when enrollment grows
            rapidly. Strong and broad government ownership is key. 2)
            The sector wide approach (SWAP) holds considerable promise.
            3) Focus on key issues is essential. Sequencing of reforms
            is of particular importance as external assistance and
            development programs are increasingly developed through
            SWAPs. 4) Policy development must be a continuous process.
            5) Decentralization, community involvement and communication
            are key elements of large-scale education reforms. 6)
            "Big Bang" policies for Universal Primary
            Education will almost inevitably result in severe disruption
            of the functioning of the system and are likely to
            jeopardize the quality of instruction.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Education Sector Adjustment
            Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The purpose of this Education Sector
            Adjustment Operation is to provide core budget support to
            promote and further develop Uganda's universal primary
            education (UPE) policy. This operation is designed to
            support the government's own priority in achieving UPE
            while also complementing other donors' interventions.
            In addition to providing budget support, the operation will
            work to 1) improve resources allocation to primary education
            particularly by paying and training additional teachers; 2)
            increase efficiency in resource use by doubleshifting and
            piloting multigrade teaching while expanding classroom
            construction; and 3) protect the quality and availability of
            education inputs, mainly by increasing the supply and
            quality of textbooks and instructional materials and by
            strengthening teacher training. Attention will also be given
            to overall sector management, planning, budgeting, and
            information systems. The adjustment operation will be
            critical in assuring that resources exist to sustain growth
            in school enrollment by assuring proper financial
            disbursements and distribution of educational inputs.
